moves.1. d4: I always open with the Queen's pawn.
moves.5... Qxc5 6. e3 Nc6 7. Nf3 Nf6 8. Bd3 O-: Preparing for the possibility of a queenside castle
moves.10... Bd7 11. O-O: Although, in this case, I feel as if a Kingside castle is better.
moves.11... Rac8 12. Na4: Trying to force the queen to move.
moves.12... Qh5 13. Be2: Preparing to move the knight to threaten Queen again.
moves.16... Rxc6 17. Nc3 Nxc3 18. bxc3 Rxc3 19: At this point, I foresee the possibility of an attack on the c pawn.
moves.21... Qf5 22. Be2: Trying to figure out what to do at this point
moves.22... Rc3xc2 23. Rxc2 Rxc2: In this exchange of rooks, I lose the pawn but gain an advantage: Black's king has lost his back-rank protection
moves.24... Rxe2: Black has failed to see this possibility and has instead gone for my unprotected bishop
moves.26. Qxe8#: Mate. I've recently been studying back rank checkmates and couldn't pass up this opportunity to practice what I've learned.
